questions.text: A 27-Year-old primigravida has been in labour for the last 25 hours and is suspected of having a Bandl’s ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment of the uterus. The resident diagnoses her to have obstructed labour and posts her for an emergency LSCS in order to deliver the baby. Which of the following terms would best describe Bandl’s ring?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pathological retraction ring Bandl's ring, also known as a pathological uterine ring, is a constriction between a woman's thickened upper contractile uterine segment and thinned lower uterine segment (LUS) during parturition. Options A, C & D. are false.

Highyeild:

Bandl's ring is a pathological retraction ring seen predominantly in obstructed labour. It is a constriction between a woman's thickened upper contractile uterine segment and thinned lower uterine segment (LUS) during parturition. The uterine muscle creates a band in which the baby's head or shoulders remains trapped, leading to the inability to deliver the infant. It is believed that prolonged labour may play a role in the development of a Bandl's ring. The constriction ring (Options C and D) also known as Schroeder's ring is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old female in labour at 41 weeks of POG. Her partogram shows uterine contraction 3/10 min for a duration of 35 seconds, the fetal head is at +1. After 1 hour of full cervical dilatation, the fetal head station is still +1. The mother due to bearing down and pushing efforts has become exhausted, dehydrated and tachypneic. Which of the following will be the management option in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait and watch and give iv fluids to mother for dehydration.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate C- section as it is a case of obstructed labour.

options.label: C
options.text: Fundal pressure with the contractions to push the head of the baby.

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate C- section as it is a case of obstructed labour.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate C- section as it is a case of obstructed labour. In the given clinical scenario, even after adequate uterine contraction, there is no descent of the presenting part of the fetus. Moreover, the mother has also become exhausted, dehydrated and tachypneic . Hence, it is a case of obstructed labou This is the same as 2nd stage arrest. The management in this case will be an immediate C- section.

Highyeild:

In obstructed labour, the mother is exhausted, tachypneic, and has acidotic breathing. The ring can be palpated between the 2 segments of PA k/s bandl’s ring. PV: Hot dry vagina, bleeding present, hematuria present. Management: Never wait and watch. Never give oxytocin. Do a C-section as soon as possible.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Wait and watch and give i.v fluids to mother for dehydration is a wrong statement. Never wait and watch in case of obstructed labour as it will lead to a risk to the life of both mother and the baby. Option: C. Fundal pressure with the contractions to push the head of the baby is not at all recommended as it can cause more shoulder retraction. Option: D. Symphysiotomy followed by vaginal delivery. Can be an alternative in selected cases of risky C - section.

Extraedge:

The most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in developing countries: obstructed labour.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old primigravida female at 42 weeks of POG is in labour. After 2 hours of full dilatation of the cervix, the female was exhausted, dehydrated with heavy breathing. The P/V findings were the same as the descent of the fetal head is not occurring. CTG monitoring reveals fetal bradycardia. The mother's PR was 120 bpm, and her BP started falling suddenly. P/A findings revealed tenderness and abdominal distension. Fetal parts were superficially palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine rupture In the given scenario, the patient has hypotension and tachycardia. Also, fetal bradycardia is present. P/A findings revealed tenderness and abdominal distension. Fetal parts were superficially palpable. All these findings suggest a ruptured uterus which is most probably due to obstructed labour.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Uterine inversion leads to unexplained death in the mother after the delivery. Option: B. Obstructed labour leads to a ruptured uterus and the findings are most suggestive of a ruptured uterus. Hence the better answer is a ruptured uterus. Option: D. Intrauterine fetal death cannot be the answer as fetal heart rate is present and not absent.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old woman with a previous history of uncomplicated C - section 2 years back is given a trial for vaginal delivery. Which of the following is the most common sign of uterine scar rupture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-reassuring fetal heart rate Progress of labour in women attempting TOLAC is similar to normal labour, and no specific pattern presages uterine rupture.

Highyeild:

The most common sign of uterine rupture is a non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern with variable decelerations that may evolve into late decelerations and bradycardia. Before hypovolemic shock develops, symptoms and physical findings in women with uterine rupture may appear bizarre unless the possibility is kept in mind.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Other signs and symptoms can also occur like maternal tachycardia and hypovolemic shock if it is not suspected and timely intervened. Option C: Mother’s falling blood pressure is also a symptom but most common sign is Non-reassuring fetal heart rate. Option: D . Hemoperitoneum can also occur and cause diaphragmatic irritation and referred pain to the chest and hence can mimic pulmonary or AFE.

questions.text: A 29-Year-old primigravida female in labour at 41 weeks of POG. On examination, she is dehydrated, and slightly pale, pulse 100 bpm, bp 130/80 mm of Hg. P/A's abdomen is tender and LUS is stretched. On P/V examination, the cervix is fully dilated, and the head is at +1 station. Her PV examination findings are the same for the next hour and the uterine contractions are decreasing. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluid electrolyte balance and correction of dehydration and ketoacidosis are done by rapid infusion of Ringer’s solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Before proceeding for definitive operative treatment, rupture of the uterus must be excluded.

options.label: C
options.text: The place of symphysiotomy has to be duly considered in developing countries as superior to cesarean section.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no place for “wait and watch”, nor is there any scope for using oxytocin to stimulate uterine contraction.

questions.correct_answer: C. The place of symphysiotomy has to be duly considered in developing countries as superior to cesarean section.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The place of symphysiotomy has to be duly considered in developing countries as superior to cesarean section. This can be done in a case of established obstruction due to outlet contraction with vertex presentation having good FHS .

Highyeild:

In the case of obstructed labour, the underlying principles are: (1) to relieve the obstruction at the earliest by a safe delivery procedure (2) to combat dehydration and ketoacidosis (3) to control sepsis. Symphysiotomy: The place of symphysiotomy has to be duly considered in the developing countries as an alternative to risky cesarean section. This can be done in a case of established obstruction due to outlet contraction with vertex presentation having good FHS .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Fluid electrolyte balance and correction of dehydration and ketoacidosis are done by rapid infusion of Ringer’s solution . This is an important step in the management of these patients. Option: B. Before proceeding with definitive operative treatment, rupture of the uterus must be excluded as a correct statement. Option: D. There is no place for “wait and watch”, neither is any scope for using oxytocin to stimulate uterine contraction is a correct statement.

questions.text: A primigravida with full-term pregnancy in labour in a remote village was managed by a dai initially, and later on, was brought to CHC. On coming, the patient was dehydrated, PR- 100 bpm, BP-110/75 mm of Hg. On P/A examination - cephalic presentation, fetal heart rate present, and uterine contractions were 3/10 min for 30 seconds duration. On P/V examination, the cervix is fully dilated, the head is at +1 station, and caput with the moulding present. She was immediately taken for the C - section with a diagnosis of obstructed labour. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the effects observed in mothers in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis is due to the accumulation of lactic acid and ketones.

options.label: B
options.text: Injury to the genital tract includes rupture of the uterus.

options.label: C
options.text: Postpartum haemorrhage and shock may be due to isolated or combined effects of the atonic uterus.

options.label: D
options.text: Exhaustion is due to constant agonizing pain and anxiety.

questions.correct_answer: A. Metabolic alkalosis is due to the accumulation of lactic acid and ketones.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic alkalosis is due to the accumulation of lactic acid and ketones. This is a wrong statement as metabolic acidosis occurs in such patients due to inadequate fluid intake.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Injury to the genital tract includes rupture of the uterus which may be spontaneous in multipara or may be traumatic following instrumental delivery . Hence it is a true statement. Option: C . Postpartum haemorrhage and shock may be due to isolated or combined effects of the atonic uterus or genital tract trauma. Option: D. Exhaustion is due to constant agonizing pain and anxiety is a correct statement.

questions.text: Blood in urine in a patient in labour is diagnostic of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obstructed labour In obstructed labour the bladder becomes an abdominal organ due to compression of the urethra between the presenting part and symphysis pubis, the patient fails to empty the bladder. The transverse depression at the junction of the superior border of the bladder and the distended lower segment is often confused with the bandl’s ring . The bladder wall gets traumatized which may lead to blood-stained urine, a common finding in obstructed labour.

Highyeild:

In obstructed labour, the mother is exhausted, tachypneic, and has acidotic breathing. The ring can be palpated between the 2 segments of PA k/s bandl’s ring. PV: Hot dry vagina, bleeding present, hematuria present. Management: Never wait and watch. Never give oxytocin . Do a C-section as soon as possible.

Extraedge:

The most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in developing countries: obstructed labour.

questions.text: The complication that can occur with the internal podalic version for transverse lie:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine rupture Internal podalic version (IPV): In modern obstetrics, there is no place for this procedure in a singleton pregnancy. The internal podalic version is only used for the second twin when it is lying transversely and the external version fails.

Highyeild:

Prerequisites for IPV: The membranes should be intact or very recently ruptured in other words liquor should be adequate. The cervix should be fully dilated. The fetus must be living.

Extraedge:

Anaesthesia: General anaesthesia (halothane). Contraindications: Obstructed labour Membranes ruptured with all the liquor drained Previous cesarean section even if it is LSCS. Contracted pelvis.

questions.text: The following statements are related to the management of obstructed labour except:

options.label: A
options.text: There is no place of wait and watch policy

options.label: B
options.text: Dehydration and ketoacidosis should be promptly corrected

options.label: C
options.text: Oxytocin has got a definite place in the management

options.label: D
options.text: Uterus should be explored as a routine the following delivery

questions.correct_answer: C. Oxytocin has got a definite place in the management
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxytocin has got a definite place in the management Options A, B and D are true statements.

Highyeild:

Principles for the management of obstructed labour: To relieve the obstruction at the earliest by a safe delivery procedure (there is no place for wait and watch). To combat dehydration and ketoacidosis. To control sepsis.

Extraedge:

Rupture of the uterus and vesicovaginal fistulas are complications.

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding the ventouse [vacuum extractor]?

options.label: A
options.text: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequent than forceps.

options.label: B
options.text: Can be applied when the fetal head is above the level of ischial spine.

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal trauma is more frequent than forceps.

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be used when the fetal head is not fully rotated.

questions.correct_answer: A. Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequent than forceps.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequent than forceps. Neonate: Superficial scalp abrasion Sloughing of the scalp and Cephalhematoma—due to rupture of emissary veins beneath the periosteum. Usually, it resolves in one or two weeks Subaponeurotic (subgaleal) haemorrhage (not limited by suture line as it is not subperiosteal) Intracranial haemorrhage (rare) Retinal haemorrhage (no long-term effect) Jaundice
